Burn to disc with MagicISO CD & DVD burner.

I can confirm that this works with a Sony laptop with a previous Vista Business installation.

My hard drive in my FE890 croaked so I got a new shiny, faster 320GB WD. :D But, I didn't make recovery dvds for  the preinstalled Vista, so I was forced to install XP. Driver hell ensued, but I got it working in a week.

I read that Vista SP1 "fixes" performance issues. Being the pc breaker that I am (lol), I wanted Vista back, but Sony was being quite the bastard for the recovery dvds. So I saw this torrent, and d/led it. (had to d/l magiciso 5.4 from this website as well in order to burn the damn uif image). Used MagicISO to burn the image to a DVD (burned 2x speed on a CompUSA DVD-R medium). Backed everything up and booted off the dvd. I selected the Sony installation (weird, it said simplified chinese instead of english). I erased the whole HD, then installed. System rebooted like 3 or 5 times after installing. lol. The system was activated, and it is genuine. I managed to update completely via Windows Update.

I d/led the standalone SP1. It didn't want to install at first because it complained about having an unsupported language. I remembered the installation quirk where it said simplified chinese, so I checked and saw that both english AND chinese languages were installed. It was just a matter of removing the chinese pack (control panel-> regional and language options->keyboards and languages->install/remove languages) and voila, SP1 installed. Took an hour.

Windows is still genuine, still activated, and everything is running smoothly. So far, I HAVE noticed a considerable performance boost when opening menus or windows.

Now to reverse-integrate it! :D ...whatever that is.

LOL! I put  XP on my computer after nuking off Vista thinking I could back door into Vista recovery but didn't know I couldn't dual boot XP & Vista!  Ran into driver hell myself. Would not recognize my DVD drive and would not let me connect to the internet so I could download new drivers!  So this really did save my but!
P.S. Sorry about the double post-spastic finger!

I have used this on my sony laptop, after stupidly deleting my recovery partition that had vista installed. I had vista basic though, and this version worked with no problems. I had all my drivers too, which is rare as sony laptops are known to have driver issues with vista. 
Also, to check for genuine status of this, i downloaded and installed every single update through windows update. This vista is still working fine, and still activated.
Around an hour ago, i ran the SP1 Update through windows update, and this ran smoothly and vista is still activated with no problems at all.

This is certainly the best format of vista i have come across, and for those of you with XP looking to upgrade, you should find no problems at all with this.

The only main problem i came across with this was the file format itself, but using magiciso, as mentioned earlier, you can burn through magic iso, however i found it easier to just open up the file in magiciso, then drag the files onto your desktop, and burn onto dvd using nero or something similar.
